text: Welcome back.

In the last segment
of this section,

we're going to see an example of
hierarchical clustering applied
to a study of breast cancer.

So this is the last
part of the segment.

This is an example
which, actually, Trevor

and I are both involved
in, actually, 10 years ago

now with a postdoc at Stanford
in oncology, Therese Sorlie.

Therese had measured gene
expression from gene chips

for about 88 women
who had breast cancer,

were being treated
for breast cancer,

and gene expression measurements
for about 8,000 genes.

So what that means is for
each of the 88 patients,

there's a quantitative
measurement for each of 8,000

genes, which measures how
much that gene was expressing,

how active it was
for that woman.

And this is a very
common kind of study

now where people look
at gene expression

to try to understand the basis
of diseases, like breast cancer,

and figure out whether there are
subtypes of the disease, which

should be treated
in a different way.

So this is quite large,
the amount of data,

with 88 patients,
8,000 features.

The group used average linkage
with correlation metric,

again, because this
is the case where

genes are in the same
units, in a sense,

but-- they're measured
in the same units,

but the actual level
of gene expression

wasn't very reliable
because it varies
across the way it's measured.

But thought to be more
important was the shape

of the relative expression
of different genes
for the same patient.

So that's why we use
correlation metric.

And we did hierarchical
clustering of the samples
with the 88 patients.

Now, when Theresa first
used the full set of genes,

the clustering she got
out wasn't satisfactory.
Now, what does that mean?

Well, again, it's very
subjective, but it didn't--

it wasn't very
informative to her--

to Theresa and
her collaborators.

So rather, they use
a subset of the genes
called the intrinsic genes.

So this is a way of choosing
a more informative subset
of genes.

And I won't go
into detail except

to say in words, in
this particular study,

these women were
given chemotherapy.

And there was actually
a sample taken
before and after for each woman.

And gene expression measurements
were available before and after.

So what Theresa
did was she defined
what called intrinsic genes.

So for each woman,
for each gene,

for each woman we look to see
which genes had the smallest
variation within a women--

within a woman, as opposed
to between the 88 women.

And the ones with the
smallest variation

were defined to be the
intrinsic genes, the 500 most--

it's the 500 genes
with lowest variation.

The idea being-- again, this
is a biological concept,

was that genes which
didn't vary much in a woman

before and after
chemotherapy compared

to the between
women variation were

thought to be intrinsic
to her cell biology.

So they were thought to be
the ones that could best

drive the clustering and
separate the women in terms
of their biology and maybe--
Their response to treatment.

They varied a lot between
women, but a little within women

across the two
repeated measures.

So doing that, we got
the following clustering.
So what do we see here?
First of all, this is the--

here are the 500 or
so intrinsic genes.
And this is called a heat map.

And this is a common display
for this kind of data.
So what do we see here?

Each row of the heat map
is a gene, 500 or so genes.

Each column is a woman,
one of the 88 women.

And each pixel is displayed
as either green, which

is negative-- so gene
expression, it's normalized.

So it runs from something
like minus 5 to plus 5.

So green would be negative
and red is positive.

So green means the
gene expression

for that gene for that
woman is lower than average,

and red means it's
higher than average.

And what's been done here is we
applied hierarchical clustering

to the columns,
that's the women,
in the way I just described.

In addition,
hierarchical clustering
was done to the rows, the genes.

This is done in both
directions, and that's
why this picture looks--

it has patches of red and green
because we've sorted them.
Basically, we've sorted the--

the hierachical clustering,
we sorted the observations

by the order of the
leaves in the tree,

both for genes and both
for-- and for samples.

And that's why if we just
display the data in the order

we obtained it, this picture
would not look so nice.

It would be a
checkerboard pattern.
It would look very random.

But see here, it looks
much more structured

because of the clustering
has been applied

and the ordering
of the leaves has

been used to reorder
the rows and columns.

This kind of
display was actually

start used first at Stanford
in the genomics labs

and around the time the
gene chip was invented,

which was also done
partly here at Stanford.

And I think this has
become very attractive just

because it's just a--
it's a nice way just
to see all the data.

If you have-- if you're given
a data set of 88 observations,

women, in 8,000 genes, that's
a lot of data just to even look
at.

And so the first challenge is,
how do I just make a display

so I can look at all the data
and see the gross patterns?

And here, this is actually
a very effective display.

This is one of the
pioneering efforts

in the labs of Patrick
Brown and David Botstein

where gene expression
really started.

So it's funny to think that
a pioneering piece of science

is actually a display,
but that's often the case.

Some very simple things
which might be seen trivial,

actually, can have
a lot of impact.

In this case, just the
ability to look at,

to arrange, and display the data
informatively was very useful,
and it's still used a lot today.
So here's the full heat map.

And then the clustering
tree is at the top.

This is here, and it's
been expanded out here.

And it's been divided into 1,
2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8 clusters.

The gray is just
basically unknown group,

but the other clusters
have been labeled by names,

like normal, basal,
ERBB2, luminal A,

luminal B. These names
were chosen by Theresa

and collaborators
based on the genes that
were expressing in the groups.

So now if we look
at this picture,

all we've taken this
the same clusters.

And we've just taken subsets
of the rows, that's these five

groups, and these
are genes which

are expressing highly in one
or more of these key groups.
Like, for example here.
Let's see.

This block of C genes
is expressing highly

in the red group
and the blue group.

This block of D genes
expressing highly
in these clusters, et cetera.

So then the oncologist
will look at this

and they'll try to
understand, well,

how are the-- so these groups
are different with respect
to these particular genes.

What do these genes
do in the cells

and what does it tell us
about these subgroups.

In particular, under the
last display of this,

if you look at these
subgroups and you

look at their survival
of these women,

these are called
Kaplan-Meier survival curves.

These women were
treated for cancer

and followed up to see how--
and hopefully recovered.

Some didn't, and the
survival curves of the groups
are given here.

So for example,
the basal group, I

believe in the purple--
which groups are those?

Basal and ERBB2 are
doing not nearly as well.

Their probability of
survival is much worse

whereas this group-- did
not group-- the luminal A is
doing much better.

So because the survival
is quite different,

the scientists
were really wanting

to find out how are these groups
different and with respect
to what genes.

And that gives us
a clue as to how

the diseases might be different,
in the different groups.

So that's an example
of clustering

for in a real scientific
problem that's of importance.

So just to wrap up
this section now,

unsupervised learning
has been the topic.

We've talked about principal
components and clustering,

and they're important in general
for understanding the variation

and grouping structure of
a set of unlabeled data.

So they can be useful
for themselves--

just by themselves as
we saw, for example,

in that last example,
or as a preprocessor

to choose a linear
combination of features
for supervised learning.

And we also saw
that the problem is

intrinsically harder
than supervised

learning because
there's no label.
There's no gold standard.

So we can't use-- you can't use
prediction error to figure out
how well we're doing.

We've just shown
you two techniques

in these presentations,
principal components

and clustering, and those
are part of a big tool bag
of lots of other techniques.

Some of them are listed here
like self-organizing maps,

independent component
analysis, spectral clustering,
and many more.

Many more of these are
covered in our book, Elements

of Statistical
Learning, in Chapter 14.

And even beyond that, there
are many others as well.
